abstract: Sallie Krawcheck has purchased just over $1 million of Bank of America stock, a little more than a week after becoming head of global wealth and investment management there.
snippet: Sallie Krawcheck has purchased just over $1 million of Bank of America stock, a little more than a week after becoming head of global wealth and investment management there.
lead_paragraph: Sallie Krawcheck has purchased just over $1 million of Bank of America stock, a little more than a week after becoming head of global wealth and investment management at the bank, the largest in the United States.

headline.main: Krawcheck Buys $1 Million in Bank of America Stock

abstract: Federal judges rejected prearranged deals in the Bank of America/Merrill Lynch and Madoff cases. One was a good move, the other perhaps not.
snippet: Federal judges rejected prearranged deals in the Bank of America/Merrill Lynch and Madoff cases. One was a good move, the other perhaps not.
lead_paragraph: Jed S. Rakoff and Richard J. Sullivan, both judges on the Federal District Court, have courtrooms seven floors apart in the United States courthouse in Lower Manhattan. Judge Rakoff, appointed by Bill Clinton in 1996, is a veteran of the bench, with a well-earned reputation for being a jurist’s jurist. With his white beard, he looks a little like Santa Claus, only more distinguished. He is 66 years old.

headline.print_headline: On Deals, Two Judges Just Say No

abstract: That would be Judge Jed Rakoff and Judge Richard Sullivan, both of whom this week said no to the government.
snippet: That would be Judge Jed Rakoff and Judge Richard Sullivan, both of whom this week said no to the government.
lead_paragraph: That would be Judge Jed Rakoff and Judge Richard Sullivan, both of whom this week said no to the government. Judge Rakoff refused to sign off on consent decree that the S.E.C. negotiated with Bank of America regarding its lack of disclosure about those now-infamous Merrill Lynch bonuses. His prodding is likely to force Bank of America to tell the country more about the issues surrounding the bonuses than any of the three loud but generally pointless Congressional hearings.
